title: UEFA Survived the Super League. But Soccer’s Storm Isn’t Over.
sub_head: Long-term financial challenges mean that European soccer and its governing body are still scrambling for new sources of revenue
body:
On the strangest Monday morning of Aleksander Ceferin’s career, the president of European soccer’s governing body had planned to deliver a dull press conference on reforms to the Champions League.
Instead, following the news that 12 elite clubs were setting up a rival Super League, he found himself railing against the former friends he now called liars, cynics, and snakes in his midst. “I have seen many things in my life—I was a criminal lawyer,” he said. “I have never seen people like that.”
Twenty-four hours later, the threat had collapsed. This version of the Super League was dead. But as Ceferin and his organization, UEFA, know too well, the forces that led to its creation are not.
After all, they are the same forces that motivated the biggest—and most controversial—overhaul of the Champions League in 20 years: an expansion from 32 to 36 teams and guarantees that each team plays more games.
As the Super League furor cooled off, a new one over the revised Champions League quickly began.
